vulnerability_information:
Hello,
We can bomb (spam) any email we want using your website. 
POC : 
1.register
2.go to https://gratipay.com/~hussein98d/emails/ and add your victim's email
3.start intercepting requests and click on "resend"
4.replay the same request many time , the victim's email will be spammed with Gratipay messages.

Thanks,
Hussein
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello,
We can bomb (spam) any email we want using your website.
POC :
1.register
2.go to https://gratipay.com/~hussein98d/emails/ and add your victim's email
3.start intercepting requests and click on "resend"
4.replay the same request many time , the victim's email will be spammed with Gratipay messages.

Thanks,
Hussein

activities.message: Alright, so we can either fix this by throttling when we place new messages on the send queue, or take them off. If we throttle when we take messages off, then we should also expire stale messages (to avoid simply sending 10,000 emails over a week instead of all at once, or whatever).

Cool, thanks @pjz.

Here's the rest of the convo for full context:

> Strawman:
>
Add columns: requested(timestamp), sent (timestamp)
>
On enqueue: update/insert including requested time.
>
On dequeue: send any with null sent column, set their sent column to now, delete any rows with sent time > 5min ago

And then:

> Well, it's really just a way of ensuring there's never more than 1requedt every 5min. Doing update/insert instead of always insert on enqueue is the real throttle as it means only one request per participant('when we place new messages on the send queue'); the final removal is the removal of the throttle.
activities.markdown_message:
Cool, thanks @pjz.

Here's the rest of the convo for full context:

Strawman:

Add columns: requested(timestamp), sent (timestamp)

On enqueue: update/insert including requested time.

On dequeue: send any with null sent column, set their sent column to now, delete any rows with sent time > 5min ago

And then:

Well, it's really just a way of ensuring there's never more than 1requedt every 5min. Doing update/insert instead of always insert on enqueue is the real throttle as it means only one request per participant('when we place new messages on the send queue'); the final removal is the removal of the throttle.

activities.message:
Copied over from Github:

Thoughts -

- We should place this constraint only for user-triggered emails (currently only for adding an email and resending a verification link). If we don't, it's likely that code we write (introductory emails etc.) will trigger the error - and this error can be hard to predict because of the time interval involved.

- Should the constraint be based on the 'to' address only? or should it be based on the person who is triggering the request?

activities.message:
@rohitpaulk The implementation in GH-1 fulfills the first of your points, in that it only touches `add_email`. It uses the `verification_start` timestamp field that we already have in the database, and performs an additional check based on that to go along with the other checks we're already performing in that method (raising `EmailAlreadyTaken`, `TooManyEmailAddresses`—we now also raise `ResendingTooFast`). The constraint in this case is therefore only on the `to` address.

You raise a good point that we also could/should be sniffing for the authenticated user that is potentially abusing the system. Would it be enough to move the `add_event` call to the beginning of the method? I suppose really we should wrap the whole thing in a `try`/`except` so that we can log both success and failure events. Eh?

activities.message:
> I'm seeing all your conversations.

Yes, that is intentional.

> Please can you talk in private?

No, we would strongly prefer not to. We are an open company, meaning (in part) that we publicly share as much of our internal decision-making as possible. On the one hand, we want you as a researcher to have visibility into our process for fixing issues while we're fixing them. What better way to be up-to-date on the status of your report? On the other hand, we want to disclose our entire conversation when we publish this ticket after the fix has been deployed and confirmed. I'm not 100% sure, but I expect that "Team only" comments will remain private even after a ticket is disclosed. I guess we'll soon get to find out for sure! :-)
